notable_quotes.speaker: Marguitte about brother
notable_quotes.french: lequel il ne print pas peine de rachepter
notable_quotes.english: which he did not take pains to redeem/ransom
notable_quotes.context: About brother not trying to save father from execution

notable_quotes.speaker: Marguitte about son going into service
notable_quotes.french: que le diable n'avoit rien que ce qu'on luy bailloit
notable_quotes.english: that the devil had nothing but what was given to him
notable_quotes.context: When one of her sons did not want to go into service

notable_quotes.speaker: Claude Mengeot to Marguitte
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoit pour savoir a la verité sy elle estoit sorciere, comme la bruict en estoit, et la faire brusler par la justice s'il luy mesadvenoit par ses maléfices
notable_quotes.english: that it was to know for truth if she was a witch, as the rumor was, and to have her burned by justice if he suffered misfortune from her malefices
notable_quotes.context: Mengeot's response when she asked why he took the meadow

notable_quotes.speaker: Marguitte's husband Chrestien Colas Thierry
notable_quotes.french: s'il venoit une bonne année, et eut un peu de grain avant main
notable_quotes.english: if a good year came, and he had a little grain ahead
notable_quotes.context: Husband saying he would have her arrested if he had resources

notable_quotes.speaker: Marguitte under torture about making hail
notable_quotes.french: dict comme elle estoit pitoyable envers le pauvre monde, elle empeschoit a cela, et n'en a aydé a faire pour gaster les biens qui estoient aux champs pour ce subject
notable_quotes.english: said that as she was compassionate toward poor people, she prevented that, and did not help make it to spoil the goods that were in the fields for this reason
notable_quotes.context: Asked about making hail at sabbat

economic_context.details: Multiple economic tensions: dispute over shared field with brother; quarrel with tutor over payments; disputes over meadow rental; latrine boundaries; payment for animal minding services; father's house confiscated and auctioned after execution. Accused's husband said he would have her arrested if he had resources ('if a good year came, and he had a little grain ahead'). Marguitte expressed concern that if brother denounced her, her children would be 'left poor and deserted.'

harms_catalog.harm_description: 10-week illness, became as if possessed; slow cure began when accused gave him millet

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Story about disappearing in woods for 5 days - accused said she was afraid to return after losing father's cows, found next day by grandmother (not 5 days by father)

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony. Some ambiguity about first husband's name - appears as both Jean Bonipaire and Jean Didier Babel in different contexts; may be same person or two different husbands. Confession obtained under torture (withstood thumbscrews, confessed on rack). Accused from family with strong witchcraft history (mother, father, maternal uncle all executed). Economic hardship evident throughout. Multiple witnesses reported being called witch without seeking legal redress. Husband himself suspected her and said he would have her arrested if he had resources. Notable that accused claimed compassion at sabbat, refusing to help make hail to harm crops. Value of 'thousand francs' for animal losses (witness 15) indicates significant economic impact.
